title: House sparrow sitting on wild angelica
alt: A house sparrow sitting on a branch of dry wild angelica
fact: House sparrows are excellent city birds—they’ve learned to open automatic doors by hopping on sensors and often hang out near cafés to snag crumbs!

title: Drake Mallard taking a dive
alt: A drake mallard diving with its head underwater
fact: Male Mallards have vibrant green heads—but they molt after breeding season and look like females for a while!

title: House sparrow basking in the sun
alt: A female house sparrow perched on a branch
fact: These little city birds have lived alongside humans for thousands of years—some nests even show up in traffic lights!

title: Willow Warbler hiding in a young tree
alt: A willow warbler hiding in a tree full of leaves
fact: It’s one of Europe’s longest-distance migrants—flying over 10,000 km to sub-Saharan Africa each year!

title: Eurasian yellow wagtail sitting by the river
alt: A yellow wagtail sitting on a rock by the river
fact: True to its name, it constantly wags its tail—possibly to flush out insects from grass.

title: Eurasian blue tit sitting on top of a black alder
alt: A eurasian blue tit sitting on top of a black alder
fact: These smart birds can remember which milk bottles had cream—famously pecking through foil lids in the UK!

title: Eurasian blackcap hiding in a dense tree
alt: A eurasian blackcap hiding in a dense tree
fact: Some Eurasian Blackcaps now migrate to the UK for winter instead of the Mediterranean—evolving new traits thanks to garden bird feeders!

title: Drake mallard looking down a river
alt: A drake mallard sitting at the edge of a river on top of some stones looking down said river
fact: That classic “quack” sound? It’s actually the female Mallard! Drakes are mostly quiet or make softer raspy sounds. So if you hear a loud quack—it’s probably not the guy!

title: Eurasian blackcap looking for food
alt: A eurasian blackcap sitting in a tree looking out for food
fact: Despite its name, only the males have the signature black cap—females wear a reddish-brown one instead.

title: Male blackbird hiding in the grass
alt: A male blackbird hiding in thick grass
fact: Male blackbirds can be super territorial—they’ll fiercely chase off rivals and even attack their own reflection thinking it's an intruder!

title: Female blackbird collecting moss
alt: A female blackbird collecting moss in its beak
fact: Female blackbirds often start building the nest alone and can complete it in just a few days using grass, mud, and twigs.

title: European red robin sitting on his throne
alt: A european red robin sitting on top of a tree-stump
fact: Despite their cute look, robins are surprisingly fierce—they’re super territorial and will even fight to the death over their patch of land!

title: Drake mallard balancing on one leg
alt: A european red robin sitting on top of a tree-stump
fact: Drake mallards often stand on one leg to help conserve body heat. By tucking one leg into their feathers, they minimize heat loss, especially in colder environments.
